abstractContent.text: Metagrammaticai formalisms that combine context-free phrase structure rules and metarules (MPS grammars) allow concise statement of generalizations about the syntax of natural languages.
Unconstrained MPS grammars, tmfortunately, are not cornputationally "safe."
We evaluate several proposals for constraining them, basing our amae~ment on computational trac-tability and explanatory adequacy.
We show that none of them satisfies both criteria, and suggest new directions for research on alternative metagrammatical formalisms.

introductionContent.text: The computational-linguistics community has recently shown interest in a variety of metagrammatical formalisms for encoding grammars of natural language.
A common technique found in these formalisms involves the notion of a metarule, which, in its most common conception, is a device used to generate grammar rules from other given grammar rules.
